div1.p: Cunningham comments on Reed's essay about her father and provides a few of her own memories about Walter Reed. She includes a transcription of a letter written to her by Emilie Lawrence Reed.

div1.head: Note from Eileen R. Cunningham, [October 10, 1957]
div1.p:
When I was a little girl, I too, had the privilege of knowing Major Reed and the
“Hillside” so vividly described by his daughter. Our summer home adjoined that of
Major Reed and our wire fence separated the lawns and gardens crossed by an oldfashioned
stile. How often I made use of it would probably have been embarrassing to my family
had they known of each visit. Luckily for me, he loved children and being of unfailing
courtesy and patience I was welcome to follow him about as he worked and to listen to
his unfailing fund of stories about frontier life and Indians. How well I remember
my father's fgrief that gloomy November afternoon in 1902 when he heard the sad news
of his death for they were good friends and continually exchanging views on their plans
as “amateur farmers”. I saw his daughter in June 1957 when visiting our old home
at Blue Ridge Summit. Her little tribute to her father's memory gives an intimate
portrait of him which only his daughter could draw. Families of great men sometimes
pay a great price for the extra strain on nerves and health imposed by their achievements
on front line battles for suffering humanity. Certainly his gay,19 year old daughter
found her life irrevocably altered by his untimely passing and a little 8 year old
neighbor joined in her sorrow. I can remember so well those lovely, sunny summer days
of his last few vacations and the subsequent saddened lives of his family as they lived
on each summer in the home he planned.

As part of the regular course in medical history I gave a lecture on the history
of yellow fever, including of course, Walter Reeds work. I asked his widow for a
picture of their summer home to show the students and she sent it with this letter:

div1.head: Letter from Blossom Lawrence Reed to Eileen R. Cunningham, March 6, 1935
div1.opener:
The Burlington Hotel Vermont Ave., Washington D.C.
March 6, 1935.
Dear Eileen:
div1.p:
It gave me much pleasure to receive your cordial letter. I am
just back from Blue Ridge Summit where Blossom has built a lovely “Inn”
and is having the most wonderful success in running. I live there with
her now for the summer months. and I am sending you the only picture I
have down here of the old home.
Note from Eileen R. Cunningham contd. 2

My hearty greetings to each and every one of the medical students and
tell them there is a warm spot in my heart for all doctors. My wishes are that some
of them may grow to have the fame that was and is Walter Reed's:

Tell them (the students) that Dr. Reed and I both loved that home and
that it was there we knew you as a little neighbor. The last talk I ever had with my
dear husband just before he was taken to the hospital for that fatal operation, was,
what we would do early the next spring in our garden.

closer.salute:
With my love to you dear Eileen,
Affectionately,
